name: LHS 1140
scenarioDescription:
The LHS 1140 Exoplanetary System

LHS 1140 is a star with 0.18 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.21 times its radius. It is located 48.89 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 5 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

LHS 1140 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

LHS 1140 c

LHS 1140 c was discovered by the Multiple Observatories observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.03 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 3.78 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, LHS 1140.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.31, which means that when LHS 1140 c is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.02 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 0.04. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of LHS 1140 c is 1.81 times the mass of Earth. The radius of LHS 1140 c is 1.282 that of Earth. At 1.81 Earth masses, LHS 1140 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

LHS 1140 b

LHS 1140 b was discovered by the MEarth Project observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.09 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 24.74 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, LHS 1140.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.06, which means that when LHS 1140 b is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.09 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 0.10. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of LHS 1140 b is 6.98 times the mass of Earth. The radius of LHS 1140 b is 1.727 that of Earth. At 6.98 Earth masses, LHS 1140 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

With a semi-major axis of 0.0936 astronomical units, and a mass of 6.98 Earth masses, LHS 1140 b could, potentially, be a habitable planet with stable bodies of liquid water on its surface, like Earth.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system LHS 1140, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Multiple Observatories.
